5:T7ec,### Scope and Coverage
We performed a comprehensive QA pass across **9 URLs** (with **3 remaining in queue**) over **7471.40 seconds**. The run combined automated accessibility checks and site structure verification to surface issues that affect usability and compliance.

### High-Level Result
Overall, this test identified **49 issues**, with several that merit prompt attention. This indicates the site has good testability and automated coverage in place, and that focused remediation will significantly improve accessibility and structure.

### Key Findings
- Missing level-one heading (H1) on pages — impacts document structure and SEO. **Next steps:** reproduce on affected pages, add a single top-level H1 per document, and update templates. Add regression tests to prevent regressions.
- No bypass mechanism for navigation (missing skip link or heading-based bypass) — affects keyboard and screen-reader users. **Next steps:** implement a visible or focusable skip link or ensure heading order supports quick navigation; validate with keyboard-only testing.
- No main landmark found (missing `<main>` or role="main`) — prevents assistive tech from locating primary content. **Next steps:** add a single `<main>` element or role="main" per page; rerun accessibility audits and include checks in CI.
- Reproduce, document, and prioritize fixes by impact (address the critical accessibility items first). Include test cases for each fix.

### Strengths to Build On
- Automated audits are running and surfaced clear, actionable items.
- Multiple pages were covered in a single run, showing good breadth of testing.
- The team has a solid basis to integrate fixes into templates and CI regression checks.

### Moving Forward
Use these findings as momentum: prioritize critical accessibility fixes, extend coverage to the remaining 3 URLs, add automated checks to CI, and perform targeted manual validation (keyboard & screen reader). Incremental improvements will raise quality steadily — you’re on the right
